p: There are connections between age, diet, nutrients, and immunity in the elders [ 37]. The clinical or subclinical micronutrient deficiency is common in older adults, which contributes to several age-related diseases and decreased immune functions [ 38, 39]. This prevalence is probably the consequence of the low appetite and the nature of little diversification of their dietary patterns in the elders. The nutritional assessment and proper management are, therefore, essential to determine the risk of infection, the illness course, and the outcome of COVID-19 in older adults [ 25].
